His style was a careful balance between French Baroque architecture and French neoclassicism.

entities.title: École Militaire
entities.description: The École militaire is a complex of buildings in Paris, France, which house various military training facilities. It was founded in 1750 by King Louis XV and is located in the 7th arrondissement of Paris, southeast of the Champ de Mars.

heading: Deaths
txt: Moses Mendelssohn, German philosopher and theologian (b. 1729)

entities.title: Moses Mendelssohn
entities.description: Moses Mendelssohn was a German-Jewish philosopher to whose ideas the Haskalah, the 'Jewish Enlightenment' of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, is indebted.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charlotte Lennox, English author and poet (b. 1730)

entities.title: Charlotte Lennox
entities.description: Charlotte Lennox, née Ramsay, was a Scottish novelist, playwright and poet, mostly remembered today as the author of The Female Quixote, and for her association with Samuel Johnson, Joshua Reynolds and Samuel Richardson. However, she had a long career in her own right.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American nun and saint (b. 1774)

entities.title: Elizabeth Ann Seton
entities.description: Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, SC, was a Catholic religious sister in the United States and an educator, known as a founder of the country's parochial school system. After her death, she became the first person born in what would become the United States to be canonized by the Catholic Church. She also established the first Catholic girls' school in the nation in Emmitsburg, Maryland, where she likew

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies (b. 1751)

entities.title: Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies
entities.description: Ferdinand I, was the King of the Two Sicilies from 1816, after his restoration following victory in the Napoleonic Wars. Before that he had been, since 1759, Ferdinand IV of the Kingdom of Naples and Ferdinand III of the Kingdom of Sicily. He was also King of Gozo. He was deposed twice from the throne of Naples: once by the revolutionary Parthenopean Republic for six months in 1799 and again by Na

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Hanson, American general (b. 1827)

entities.title: Roger Hanson
entities.description: Roger Weightman Hanson was a brigadier general in the Confederate States Army during the American Civil War. The commander of the famed "Orphan Brigade," he was mortally wounded at the Battle of Murfreesboro. He was nicknamed "Old Flintlock."

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Gregson, English-Australian lawyer and politician, 2nd Premier of Tasmania (b. 1798)

entities.title: Thomas Gregson
entities.description: Thomas George Gregson was the second Premier of Tasmania, serving from 26 February 1857 until 25 April 1857.

entities.title: Premier of Tasmania
entities.description: The Premier of Tasmania is the head of the executive government in the Australian state of Tasmania. By convention, the leader of the party or political grouping which has majority support in the House of Assembly is invited by the Governor of Tasmania to be Premier and principal adviser.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cornelius Vanderbilt, American businessman and philanthropist (b. 1794)

entities.title: Cornelius Vanderbilt
entities.description: Cornelius Vanderbilt was an American business magnate who built his wealth in railroads and shipping. After working with his father's business, Vanderbilt worked his way into leadership positions in the inland water trade and invested in the rapidly growing railroad industry. Nicknamed "The Commodore", he is known for owning the New York Central Railroad. His biographer T. J. Stiles says, "He vast

heading: Deaths
txt: Anselm Feuerbach, German painter and educator (b. 1829)

entities.title: Anselm Feuerbach
entities.description: Anselm Feuerbach was a German painter. He was the leading classicist painter of the German 19th-century school.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward William Cooke, English painter and illustrator (b. 1811)

heading: Deaths
txt: John William Draper, English-American physician, chemist, and photographer (b. 1811)

entities.title: John William Draper
entities.description: John William Draper was an English-born American scientist, philosopher, physician, chemist, historian and photographer. He is credited with producing the first clear photograph of a female face (1839–40) and the first detailed photograph of the moon in 1840. He was also the first president of the American Chemical Society (1876–77) and a founder of the New York University School of Medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antoine Chanzy, French general (b. 1823)

entities.title: Antoine Chanzy
entities.description: Antoine Eugène Alfred Chanzy was a French general, notable for his successes during the Franco-Prussian War and as a governor of Algeria.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antoine Labelle, Canadian priest (b. 1833)

entities.title: Antoine Labelle
entities.description: François-Xavier-Antoine Labelle was a Roman Catholic priest and the person principally responsible for the settlement of the Laurentians. He is also referred to as "Curé Labelle" and sometimes, the "King of the North."

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Hubert Reinkens, German bishop and academic (b. 1821)

entities.title: Joseph Hubert Reinkens
entities.description: Joseph Hubert Reinkens was the first German Old Catholic bishop.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stanisław Mieroszewski, Polish-born politician, writer, historian and member of the Imperial Council of Austria (b. 1827)

entities.title: Stanisław Mieroszewski
entities.description: Count Stanisław Mieroszewski (Mieroszowski) (1827–1900) was a Polish-born politician, writer, historian and member of the Imperial Council of Austria.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolaos Gyzis, Greek painter and academic (b. 1842)

entities.title: Nikolaos Gyzis
entities.description: Nikolaos Gyzis was considered one of Greece's most important 19th-century painters. He was most famous for his work Eros and the Painter, his first genre painting. It was auctioned in May 2006 at Bonhams in London, being last exhibited in Greece in 1928. He was the major representative of the so-called "Munich School", the major 19th-century Greek art movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Winlock, American astronomer and academic (b. 1857)

entities.title: Anna Winlock
entities.description: Anna Winlock (1857–1904) was an American astronomer and human computer, one of the first members of female computer group known as "the Harvard Computers." She made the most complete catalog of stars near the north and south poles of her era. She is also remembered for her calculations and studies of asteroids. In particular, she did calculations on 433 Eros and 475 Ocllo.

heading: Deaths
txt: Léon Delagrange, French pilot and sculptor (b. 1873)

entities.title: Léon Delagrange
entities.description: Ferdinand Léon Delagrange was a pioneering French aviator and sculptor. Léon was ranked as one of the top aviators in the world. On 30 December 1909 he had broken all speed records at Juvisy-sur-Orge in France in an attempt to win the Michelin Cup. He did not succeed in beating Henry Farman’s record for distance, but did establish a new distance record for monoplanes and a new world speed record.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clarence Dutton, American geologist and soldier (b. 1841)

entities.title: Clarence Dutton
entities.description: Clarence Edward Dutton was an American geologist and US Army officer. Dutton was born in Wallingford, Connecticut on May 15, 1841. He graduated from Yale College in 1860 and took postgraduate courses there until 1862, when he enlisted in the 21st Connecticut Volunteer Infantry; he fought at Fredericksburg, Suffolk, Nashville and Petersburg. He was elected as a member to the American Philosophical

heading: Deaths
txt: Georg von Hertling, German academic and politician, 7th Chancellor of the German Empire (b. 1843)

entities.title: Georg von Hertling
entities.description: Georg Friedrich Karl Freiherr von Hertling was a German politician who served as the Minister-President of Bavaria from 1912 to 1917 and then as Minister-President of Prussia and Chancellor of the German Empire from 1917 to 1918. He was the first party politician to hold the office.

entities.title: Chancellor of the German Empire
entities.description: The chancellor of Germany, officially the federal chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is the head of government and chief executive of Germany, as well as the commander in chief of the German Armed Forces during wartime. The chancellor is elected by the Bundestag on the proposal of the federal president and without debate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Benito Pérez Galdós, Spanish author and playwright (b. 1843)

entities.title: Benito Pérez Galdós
entities.description: Benito Pérez Galdós was a Spanish realist novelist. He was the leading literary figure in 19th-century Spain, and some scholars consider him second only to Miguel de Cervantes in stature as a Spanish novelist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Grünfeld, Austrian pianist and composer (b. 1852)

entities.title: Alfred Grünfeld
entities.description: Alfred Grünfeld was an Austrian pianist and composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nellie Cashman, American nurse, restaurateur, entrepreneur, and gold prospector (b. 1845)

entities.title: Nellie Cashman
entities.description: Ellen "Nellie" Cashman, was an Irish nurse, restaurateur, businesswoman and philanthropist in Arizona, Alaska, British Columbia and the Yukon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Süleyman Nazif, Turkish poet and civil servant (b. 1870)

entities.title: Süleyman Nazif
entities.description: Süleyman Nazif was a Turkish poet and a prominent member of the CUP. He mastered Arabic, Persian, and French languages and worked as a civil servant during the reign of Sultan Abdul Hamid II. He contributed to the literary magazine Servet-i Fünun until it was censored by the Ottoman government in 1901.

heading: Deaths
txt: Art Acord, American actor and stuntman (b. 1890)

entities.title: Art Acord
entities.description: Arthemus Ward "Art" Acord was an American silent film actor and rodeo champion. After his film career ended in 1929, Acord worked in rodeo road shows and as a miner in Mexico.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louise, Princess Royal of the United Kingdom (b. 1867)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mohammad Ali Jouhar, Indian journalist, activist, and scholar (b. 1878)

heading: Deaths
txt: Flora Finch, English-American actress and producer (b. 1867)

entities.title: Flora Finch
entities.description: Flora Finch was an English-born vaudevillian, stage and film actress who starred in over 300 silent films, including over 200 for the Vitagraph Studios film company. Unfortunately, the vast majority of her films from the silent era are currently classified as lost.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henri Bergson, French philosopher and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1859)

entities.title: Henri Bergson
entities.description: Henri-Louis Bergson was a French philosopher who was influential in the tradition of continental philosophy, especially during the first half of the 20th century until the Second World War. Bergson is known for his arguments that processes of immediate experience and intuition are more significant than abstract rationalism and science for understanding reality.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerzy Iwanow-Szajnowicz, Greek-Polish swimmer and water polo player (b. 1911)

entities.title: Jerzy Iwanow-Szajnowicz
entities.description: Jerzy Iwanow-Szajnowicz was a Greek-Polish athlete who fought as a saboteur in the Greek Resistance during World War II and was executed by the Germans.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marina Raskova, Russian pilot and navigator (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kaj Munk, Danish playwright and pastor (b. 1898)

entities.title: Kaj Munk
entities.description: Kaj Harald Leininger Munk was a Danish playwright and Lutheran pastor, known for his cultural engagement and his martyrdom during the Occupation of Denmark of World War II. He is commemorated as a martyr in the Calendar of Saints of the Lutheran Church on 14 August, alongside Maximilian Kolbe.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Camus, French novelist, philosopher, and journalist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1913)

entities.title: Albert Camus
entities.description: Albert Camus was a French philosopher, author, and journalist. He won the Nobel Prize in Literature at the age of 44 in 1957, the second-youngest recipient in history. His works include The Stranger, The Plague, The Myth of Sisyphus, The Fall, and The Rebel.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Erwin Schrödinger, Austrian physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1887)

entities.title: Erwin Schrödinger
entities.description: Erwin Rudolf Josef Alexander Schrödinger, sometimes written as Erwin Schrodinger or Erwin Schroedinger, was a Nobel Prize-winning Austrian-Irish physicist who developed a number of fundamental results in quantum theory: the Schrödinger equation provides a way to calculate the wave function of a system and how it changes dynamically in time.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Lammers, German jurist and politician (b. 1879)

entities.title: Hans Lammers
entities.description: Hans Heinrich Lammers was a German jurist and prominent Nazi politician. From 1933 until 1945 he served as Chief of the Reich Chancellery under Adolf Hitler. During the 1948–1949 Ministries Trial, Lammers was found guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity and sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment.

heading: Deaths
txt: T. S. Eliot, American-English poet, playwright, and critic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1888)

entities.title: T. S. Eliot
entities.description: Thomas Stearns Eliot was a poet, essayist, publisher, playwright, literary critic and editor. Considered one of the 20th century's major poets, he is a central figure in English-language Modernist poetry.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Donald Campbell, English racing driver and world speed record holder (b. 1921)

entities.title: Donald Campbell
entities.description: Donald Malcolm Campbell, was a British speed record breaker who broke eight absolute world speed records on water and on land in the 1950s and 1960s. He remains the only person to set both world land and water speed records in the same year (1964). He died during a water speed record attempt at Coniston Water in the Lake District, England.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Chambers, American bassist and composer (b. 1935)

entities.title: Paul Chambers
entities.description: Paul Laurence Dunbar Chambers Jr. was a jazz double bassist. A fixture of rhythm sections during the 1950s and 1960s, his importance in the development of jazz bass can be measured not only by the extent of his work in this short period, but also by his impeccable timekeeping and virtuosic improvisations. He was also known for his bowed solos. Chambers recorded about a dozen albums as a leader or

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlo Levi, Italian painter, author, and activist (b. 1902)

entities.title: Carlo Levi
entities.description: Carlo Levi was an Italian painter, writer, activist, anti-fascist, and doctor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Horrocks, Indian-English general (b. 1895)

entities.title: Brian Horrocks
entities.description: Lieutenant-General Sir Brian Gwynne Horrocks, was a British Army officer, chiefly remembered as the commander of XXX Corps in Operation Market Garden and other operations during the Second World War. He also served in the First World War and the Russian Civil War, was taken prisoner twice, and competed in the modern pentathlon at the 1924 Paris Olympics. Later he was a television presenter, wrote

heading: Deaths
txt: Christopher Isherwood, English-American author and academic (b. 1904)

entities.title: Christopher Isherwood
entities.description: Christopher Isherwood was an Anglo-American novelist, playwright, screenwriter, autobiographer, and diarist. His best-known works include Goodbye to Berlin (1939), a semi-autobiographical novel which inspired the musical Cabaret, A Single Man (1964) adapted as a film by Tom Ford in 2009, and Christopher and His Kind (1976), a memoir which "carried him into the heart of the Gay Liberation movement"

heading: Deaths
txt: Phil Lynott, Irish singer-songwriter, bass player, and producer (b. 1949)

heading: Deaths
txt: Lily Laskine, French harp player (b. 1893)

entities.title: Lily Laskine
entities.description: Lily Laskine was one of the most prominent harpists of the twentieth century. Born Lily Aimée Laskine to Jewish parents in Paris, she studied at the Conservatoire de Paris with Alphonse Hasselmans and became a frequent performing partner of several distinguished French flautists, including Marcel Moyse and Jean-Pierre Rampal. Laskine also served as professor of harp at the Conservatoire de Paris f

heading: Deaths
txt: Harold Eugene Edgerton, American engineer and academic (b. 1903)

entities.title: Harold Eugene Edgerton
entities.description: Harold Eugene "Doc" Edgerton, also known as Papa Flash, was a professor of electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is largely credited with transforming the stroboscope from an obscure laboratory instrument into a common device. He also was deeply involved with the development of sonar and deep-sea photography, and his equipment was used by Jacques Cousteau in searc

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Bolte, Australian sergeant and politician, 38th Premier of Victoria (b. 1908)

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: R. D. Burman, Indian film composer and music director (b. 1939)

entities.title: R. D. Burman
entities.description: Rahul Dev Burman was an Indian music director. He is widely regarded as one of the most predominant musical forces that Indian cinema has ever witnessed. Burman is considered as one of the greatest music composers of the Indian film industry. From the 1960s to the 1990s, Burman composed musical scores for 331 films. Burman did major work with his wife, Asha Bhosle, and Kishore Kumar and scored man

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduardo Mata, Mexican conductor and composer (b. 1942)

entities.title: Eduardo Mata
entities.description: Eduardo Mata was a Mexican conductor and composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sol Tax, American anthropologist and academic (b. 1907)

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Helmsley, American businessman (b. 1909)

entities.title: Harry Helmsley
entities.description: Harry Brakmann Helmsley was an American real estate billionaire whose company, Helmsley-Spear, became one of the country's biggest property holders, owning the Empire State Building and many of New York's most prestigious hotels. From humble beginnings, Helmsley moved up in property through natural salesmanship, a willingness to delegate, and shrewd acquisition policies that were ahead of their ti

heading: Deaths
txt: Mae Questel, American actress (b. 1908)

entities.title: Mae Questel
entities.description: Mae Questel was an American actress and voice actress best known for providing the voices for the animated characters Betty Boop and Olive Oyl. She began in vaudeville, primarily as an artist impersonator and played occasional small roles on Broadway and on television and films, later in her career, most notably the role of Aunt Bethany in 1989's National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Iron Eyes Cody, American actor and stuntman (b. 1904)

entities.title: Iron Eyes Cody
entities.description: Iron Eyes Cody was an American actor of Italian descent who portrayed Native Americans in Hollywood films, famously as Chief Iron Eyes in Bob Hope's The Paleface (1948). He also played a Native American shedding a tear about litter in one of the country's most well-known television public service announcements from the group Keep America Beautiful. Living in Hollywood, he began to insist, even in

heading: Deaths
txt: Spyros Markezinis, Greek lawyer and politician, 170th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1909)

entities.title: Spyros Markezinis
entities.description: Spyridon Markezinis or Markesinis was a Greek politician, longtime member of the Hellenic Parliament, and briefly the Prime Minister of Greece during the aborted attempt at democratization of the Greek military regime in 1973.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Fears, Mexican-American football player and coach (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Les Brown, American bandleader and composer (b. 1912)

entities.title: Les Brown (bandleader)
entities.description: Lester Raymond Brown was an American jazz musician who led the big band Les Brown and His Band of Renown for nearly seven decades from 1938 to 2000. Brown is also the grandfather of animator Jeff 'Swampy' Marsh.

heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Gibson, English director and screenwriter (b. 1944)

entities.title: Brian Gibson (director)
entities.description: Brian Gibson was an English film director.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joan Aiken, English author (b. 1924)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Toland, American historian and author (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bud Poile, Canadian ice hockey player, coach, and manager (b. 1924)

entities.title: Bud Poile
entities.description: Norman Robert "Bud" Poile was a professional ice hockey player, coach, general manager, and league executive. Bud is the brother of Don Poile, and the father of David Poile.

txt: Frank Harary, American mathematician and academic (b. 1921)

txt: Humphrey Carpenter, English radio host and author (b. 1946)

txt: Robert Heilbroner, American economist and historian (b. 1919)

entities.description: Irving Peter Layton, OC was a Romanian-born Canadian poet. He was known for his "tell it like it is" style which won him a wide following, but also made him enemies. As T. Jacobs notes in his biography (2001), Layton fought Puritanism throughout his life:Layton's work had provided the bolt of lightning that was needed to split open the thin skin of conservatism and complacency in the poetry scene

heading: Deaths
txt: Maktoum bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Emirati politician, 1st Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates (b. 1946)

entities.title: Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates
entities.description: The prime minister of the United Arab Emirates is the head of government of the United Arab Emirates. While not required by the UAE constitution, the practice is that the emir of Dubai serve as the prime minister and vice president of the UAE.

heading: Deaths
txt: Milton Himmelfarb, American sociographer, author, and academic (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Helen Hill, American director and producer (b. 1970)

entities.title: Helen Hill
entities.description: Helen Wingard Hill was an American artist, filmmaker, writer, teacher, and social activist. When her final film, The Florestine Collection, was released in 2011, curators and critics praised her work and legacy, describing her, for example, as "one of the most well-regarded experimental animators of her generation."

heading: Deaths
txt: Steve Krantz, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: Marais Viljoen, South African politician, 5th State President of South Africa (b. 1915)

entities.title: State President of South Africa
entities.description: The State President of the Republic of South Africa was the head of state of South Africa from 1961 to 1994. The office was established when the country became a republic in 1961, and Queen Elizabeth II ceased to be monarch of South Africa. The position of Governor-General of South Africa was accordingly abolished. From 1961 to 1984, the post was largely ceremonial. After constitutional reforms en

heading: Deaths
txt: Xavier Chamorro Cardenal, Nicaraguan journalist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Xavier Chamorro Cardenal
entities.description: Xavier Chamorro Cardenal, a Nicaraguan journalist, was founding editor and publisher of El Nuevo Diario, which he founded in a Nicaraguan newspaper.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gert Jonke, Austrian poet, playwright, and author (b. 1946)

entities.title: Gert Jonke
entities.description: Gert Jonke was an Austrian poet, playwright and novelist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johan Ferrier, Surinamese educator and politician, 1st President of Suriname (b. 1910)

entities.title: Johan Ferrier
entities.description: Johan Henri Eliza Ferrier was a Surinamese politician who served as the 1st President of Suriname from 25 November 1975 to 13 August 1980. He was that country's last governor before independence, from 1968 to 1975, and first president after it gained independence from the Netherlands.

entities.title: President of Suriname
entities.description: The president of the Republic of Suriname is, in accordance with the Constitution of 1987, the head of state and head of government of Suriname, and commander-in-chief of the Suriname National Army (SNL).

txt: Tsutomu Yamaguchi, Japanese engineer (b. 1916)

entities.title: Coen Moulijn
entities.description: Coenraadt "Coen" Moulijn OON was a Dutch footballer who played for Feyenoord from 1955 to 1972 and was part of their European Cup victory in 1970.

txt: Gerry Rafferty, Scottish singer-songwriter (b. 1947)

heading: Deaths
txt: Salmaan Taseer, Pakistani businessman and politician, 26th Governor of Punjab, Pakistan (b. 1944)

entities.title: Governor of Punjab, Pakistan
entities.description: The Governor of Punjab is the appointed head of state of the provincial government in Punjab, Pakistan. Although the Governor is the head of the province on paper, it is largely a ceremonial position; and the main powers lie with the Chief Minister Punjab and Chief Secretary Punjab.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eve Arnold, American photographer and journalist (b. 1912)

entities.title: Eve Arnold
entities.description: Eve Arnold, OBE, Hon. FRPS was an American photojournalist. She joined Magnum Photos agency in 1951, and became a full member in 1957. She was the first woman to join the agency.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rod Robbie, English-Canadian architect, designed the Canadian Pavilion and Rogers Centre (b. 1928)

entities.title: Canadian Pavilion
entities.description: The Canadian Pavilion at Expo 67 in Montreal featured an inverted pyramid structure as well as a walk through an attraction called the "People Tree." The pavilion had its highest single-day attendance on Canada Day, 1967.

entities.title: Rogers Centre
entities.description: Rogers Centre is a multi-purpose stadium in Downtown Toronto, Canada, situated just southwest of the CN Tower near the northern shore of Lake Ontario. Opened in 1989 on the former Railway Lands, it is home to the Toronto Blue Jays of Major League Baseball (MLB). heading: Deaths
txt: Anwar Shamim, Pakistani general (b. 1931)

entities.title: Anwar Shamim
entities.description: Air Chief Marshal Mohammad Anwar Shamim LOM, NI(m), HI(m), SI(m), SJ, OI, was a senior air officer of the Pakistan Air Force and was the Chief of Air Staff, appointed to the post in 1978 until retiring in 1985.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pino Daniele, Italian singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1955)

entities.title: Pino Daniele
entities.description: Pino Daniele was an Italian singer-songwriter, and guitarist, whose influences covered a wide number of genres, including pop, blues, jazz, and Italian and Middle Eastern music.

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Sarosh Homi Kapadia was the thirty-eighth Chief Justice of India.

entities.description: The Chief Justice of India, officially the Chief Justice of the Republic of India, is the chief judge of the Supreme Court of India as well as the highest-ranking officer of the Indian federal judiciary. heading: Deaths

entities.title: United States Ambassador to South Korea
entities.description: The United States Ambassador to South Korea is the chief diplomatic representative of the United States accredited to the Republic of Korea. The ambassador's official title is "Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to the Republic of Korea."

heading: Deaths
txt: Milt Schmidt, Canadian ice hockey player, coach and general manager (b. 1918)

entities.title: Milt Schmidt
entities.description: Milton Conrad Schmidt was a Canadian professional ice hockey centre, coach and general manager, mostly for the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League (NHL), where he was a member of the Kraut Line. He was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1961. In 2017 Schmidt was named one of the '100 Greatest NHL Players' in history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harold Brown, 14th United States Secretary of Defense (b. 1927)

entities.title: Harold Brown (Secretary of Defense)
entities.description: Harold Brown was an American nuclear physicist who served as United States Secretary of Defense from 1977 to 1981, under President Jimmy Carter. Previously, in the John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson administrations, he held the posts of Director of Defense Research and Engineering (1961–1965) and United States Secretary of the Air Force (1965–1969).

entities.title: United States Secretary of Defense
entities.description: The United States secretary of defense (SecDef) is the leader and chief executive officer of the United States Department of Defense, the executive department of the U.S. Armed Forces. The secretary of defense's position of command and authority over the military is second only to that of the president of the United States, who is the commander-in-chief. heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Long, Australian actor (b. 1968)

entities.title: Tom Long (actor)
entities.description: Tom Long was an Australian film and television actor. He played court official and avid surfer Angus in the late 1990s TV series SeaChange and Brenden Abbott in the 2003 Australian TV movie  The Postcard Bandit.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tanya Roberts, American actress (b. 1955)

entities.title: Tanya Roberts
entities.description: Victoria Leigh Blum, known professionally as Tanya Roberts, was an American actress, producer, and model. She is best known for playing Julie Rogers in the final season of the television series Charlie's Angels (1980–1981), Stacey Sutton in the James Bond film A View to a Kill (1985), Sheena in Sheena (1984), Kiri in The Beastmaster (1982) and as Midge Pinciotti on That '70s Show (1998–2004).
